Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Patterns and processes in the evolution of nest construction in Ploceus weaverbirds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellow, Robert Habig, is conducting research and receiving training that is increasing the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The fellow is being mentored by David Lahti at Queens College, City University of New York. The goal of the fellow's project is to perform a comparative evolutionary analysis of nest construction in the weaverbirds (Ploceus spp.). The evolutionary history of behavior can be nearly intractable and resistant to quantitative analysis. One strategy for illuminating our understanding of behavioral evolution is to conduct comparative studies of animal architectures, such as nests. Unlike behaviors themselves, nests persist through time, and have structures that can be disassociated into several quantitative features, which permits easy and comparable measurements and allows scientists to address questions about evolutionary history and functional relevance. The fellow's research addresses two major questions: (1) How do patterns of nest construction vary within and between species? (2) How do interrelated evolutionary processes shape variation in nest structure? This project is important for advancing foundational scientific knowledge, and will be the first study of weavers incorporating both molecular data and nest morphology to better understand the evolutionary underpinnings of a complex behavioral process. The fellow is also broadening participation in science by mentoring students underrepresented in biology.

The Fellow will reconstruct the evolution of nest construction in Ploceus weaverbirds incorporating advanced phylogenetic and morphological techniques including bioinformatics, computer modeling, X-ray computed tomography, and image processing. The Fellow will also conduct fieldwork in two hotspots of weaverbird diversity, the Awash Valley in Ethiopia and the Limpopo Province of South Africa, and collect behavioral data (e.g. rates of predation and brood parasitism; mating and parental behavior) and morphological data (e.g. nest structure) to test hypotheses of how distinct types of evolutionary selection shape the evolution of nest construction. The proposed comparative study can thus address questions such as how rapidly certain nest structural features evolve, which features are ancestral versus derived, which tend to exhibit phylogenetic signal, and which evolve in response to environmental features. The Fellow is receiving training in three-dimensional morphological analyses, phylogenetic tree construction, bioinformatics, computer modeling, and mentoring skills. The plan to broaden participation includes (1) recruitment, training, and mentoring of Queens College students from underrepresented groups in biology; (2) designing an evolutionary biology curriculum that ties in the research of the fellowship; (3) teaching an evolutionary biology class to underrepresented middle and high school students at the American Museum of Natural History; and (4) facilitating a research team for middle school and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to perform a comparative evolutionary analysis of nest construction in the weaverbirds (Ploceus spp.), a group of birds thought to be among the most accomplished nest builders, as their name implies. The proposed research addressed two major questions: (1) How do patterns of nest construction vary within and between species? (2) How do interrelated evolutionary processes shape variation in nest morphologies? The research was based at Queens College, City University of New York, and the project focused intently on broadening participation of groups underrepresented in biology. This was the first study of Family Ploceidae (the weaverbirds) to incorporate both molecular data and nest morphology to better understand patterns of evolution with respect to a complex behavioral process. By using the most robust and up-to-date molecular phylogeny available, the Fellow reconstructed the macroevolutionary history of nest construction behavior in the weaverbirds. The study addressed key questions about the evolution of extended phenotypes such as how rapidly certain nest structural features evolve, which features were ancestral versus derived, which tended to exhibit phylogenetic signal, and which evolved in response to environmental features. The study also incorporated morphological and behavioral data collected in Awash National Park, Ethiopia to test hypotheses of how evolutionary processes shape the evolution of nest construction both within and between species. The data collected from fieldwork allowed for a powerful functional analysis of nest structure, especially with respect to identifying and confirming particular sources of selection in several species. Thus, the results of this project were used to address fundamental questions about natural selection and sexual selection: (1) What are sources of selection that shape morphological variation in nest architectures? (2) What features of nest architecture are associated with reproductive success?

 

One of the aims of this project was to broaden participation of individuals from groups historically underrepresented in biology. To accomplish this aim, the Fellow recruited, trained, and mentored several Queens College students from diverse backgrounds. During the mentorship, participating students learned skills that enhanced their career development, including computer coding, statistical analyses, collaboration, and scientific communication. One of the students was an author on two peer-reviewed manuscripts, several of the students have manuscripts in preparation, and one student has a manuscript currently under peer review. In addition to working with college students, the Fellow partnered with the American Museum of Natural History to provide outreach opportunities to New York City high school students. Specifically, the Fellow facilitated an evolutionary biology research team with a specific focus on the landscape genetics of the New York estuarine harbor. The goal of this study was to assess the population genetics of co-distributed species of macroinvertebrates and fishes along the waterways within and adjacent to New York City. To accomplish this aim, the Fellow worked with high school students to collect specimens from a set of locations surrounding the Long Island Sound, coastal Long Island, New York Harbor, and the lower Hudson River. During sample collection, students collected data on an array of abiotic factors including salinity, dissolved oxygen, temperature, and turbidity. Following sample collection, students incorporated genetic techniques such as DNA extraction and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification and DNA sequencing to identify organisms. In addition to species identification, DNA sequencing informed bioinformatics analyses, yielding patterns of genetic variation of co-occurring species of the littoral environment of New York Harbor. The students presented their research at a public poster symposium held at the American Museum of Natural History. Moreover, the Fellow, in conjunction with the Education Department at the American Museum of Natural History, conducted a mixed method research study on the STEM outcomes of the participants of this program. Specifically, the Fellow quantified how and to what extent participation in this outreach program impacted students’ awareness and interest in careers in biology.
